author: vors
body:
Repro:
- Run bin/powershell
- run bash
- type `ls`

Expected:
Shows "ls"

Actual:
Doesn't displayed typed symbols
- Hit enter

Expected (Actual):
ls executed

Note that bash -> powershell -> bash -> vim works fine: I can type in vim and symbols appears on the screen

Tested on 6d5194057ea55eccac00ef6566d9edc9b8862fc4 Ubuntu 14.04

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body:
I think what's happening is that `System.Console` (used in PowerShell's readline functionality) turns off the echo TTY mode, and bash doesn't explicitly turn it on (and Vim likely does).

To fix this, I think we'd have to eliminate all uses of `Console.ReadKey()` from our readline implementation.

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: Yeah that's definitely what's going on. If, after you've opened Bash, you execute `stty echo`, your characters will then be displayed as expected.

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body:
@palladia The CoreFX team would like to help us fix this bug, but would like a repro outside of PowerShell, which means writing a small console app and debugging the problem at least to the point of repro'ing in a new program.

It should involve just using `Console.ReadKey()` and starting a process, though you may have to see if PowerShell does something non-default when launching a native process.

comments.author: palladia
comments.body:
@andschwa I may have something...Take a look at \scratch2\geflem\echo_test\Program.cs, and read the comments.  I still haven't quite figure out why bash is not displaying the prompt, but try this:  If "string cmdToExecute = ReadALine()" is uncommented, compile, run, and type "/bin/bash" in first line, and "dir" in second line.  Note that "dir" is not echoed.  Type "exit" to exit.  Now, comment out that line, and uncomment "string cmdToExecute = "/bin/bash".  Build, run, and type "dir", and note that it's echoed correctly.

Let me know if you can/can't repro this.

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body:
It's not displaying it because the `echo` TTY mode gets disabled by `Console.ReadKey()`.

Sounds like you're on the right track to repro though, will take a look soon. Is that in a branch or a repo somewhere?
